channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Prince Andrew's Abuse Case Could Mean for the Royal Family
item.description: As Queen Elizabeth II prepares to mark 70 years on the throne this year, a sexual abuse case in a Manhattan court involving her son could mean more turmoil for the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Palestinian Prisoner’s Hunger Strike Leads to Release
item.description: A Palestinian accused of plotting to kill Israelis went on a hunger strike to protest his imprisonment without trial. Fearing unrest, Israel agreed to release him.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Hisham Abu Hawash, in an Israeli hospital on Sunday, with his wife, Aisha Hirbat, and a representative of the Palestinian Authority. Mr. Abu Hawash has been on a hunger strike since August.

item.title: Faced With Questions About Forced Labor in China, the I.O.C. Is Tight-Lipped
item.description: Olympic officials are reluctant to look into whether any Beijing 2022 merchandise might have been made under duress by Uyghurs, an activist group charges.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Coalition to End Forced Labor in the Uyghur Region
item.media:credit: Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Official Olympic merchandise at a store in Beijing. The International Olympic Committee has defended its sourcing practices, noting that it engages with suppliers and conducts audits.

item.title: Leftists Are Ascendant in Latin America as Key Elections Loom
item.description: Growing inequality and sputtering economies have helped fuel a wave of leftist victories that may soon extend to Brazil and Colombia.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño, Julie Turkewitz and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Xiomara Castro, who won election in Honduras, has proposed a system of universal basic income for poor families.

item.title: U.S. Charges a Suspect in Assassination of Haiti’s President
item.description: A former Colombian commando is the first to face U.S. prosecution in the killing of Jovenel Moïse, after agents flew him to Miami from Panama.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The house in Port-au Prince-where President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti was assassinated in July of last year.

item.title: How This Changing Brussels Neighborhood is Trying to Leave The Stigma of Terrorism Behind
item.description: Molenbeek was where a terrorist cell planned attacks that killed 162 in Paris and Brussels. Six years later, residents are trying to reinvent the area as a trial rekindles an awful association.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Virginie Nguyen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of residents of the Molenbeek neighborhood of Brussels traveled to Syria and Iraq to fight alongside armed groups in the early 2010s.

item.title: Mystery Deepens as Suspect Is Charged With Setting South Africa’s Parliament on Fire
item.description: The 49-year-old was also accused of possessing explosives, stealing laptops and breaking security laws. Former neighbors were shocked. His lawyer said the government was rushing to find a scapegoat.
item.dc:creator: Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Zandile Christmas Mafe was charged with arson, theft and housebreaking in connection with the fire.

item.title: Ireland Puts Minimum Price on Alcohol to Curb Binge Drinking
item.description: The new rule, part of broader legislation aimed at stemming alcohol-related illnesses, sets a minimum price of one euro per standard drink and came into effect on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Alcohol for sale in a supermarket in Galway, Ireland, on Tuesday. The country has introduced a new minimum price for alcohol in an effort to reduce binge drinking.

item.title: Petition to Rescind Tony Blair’s Knighthood Gets Hundreds of Thousands of Signatures
item.description: Nearly 15 years after he left office, the prime minister’s support for the Iraq war has not been forgiven by many in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Former British prime ministers, from left, Gordon Brown, Tony Blair and Sir John Major, in London in November.

item.title: Woman Suing Prince Andrew for Abuse Settled With Jeffrey Epstein for $500,000
item.description: The prince’s lawyers are expected to argue that Virginia Roberts Giuffre’s suit should be dismissed because of the earlier settlement’s terms.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:description: Prince Andrew, the second son of Queen Elizabeth II, has denied the allegations.

item.title: Haiti Prime Minister Survives Assassination Attempt, His Office Says
item.description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry was the target of an unsuccessful attempt on his life over the weekend by gunmen in the northern city of Gonaïves, his office said Monday night.
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Ariel Henry of Haiti speaking at the inauguration ceremony of his culture minister, in Port-au-Prince in November.

item.title: Sudan Braces for ‘the Worst’ after Prime Minister Resigns
item.description: With the departure of the civilian prime minister Abdalla Hamdok on Sunday, the military and security forces are now fully in control of Sudan again.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: People chant slogans during a protest to denounce the October 2021 military coup, in Khartoum on Sunday.

item.title: How the European Union Allowed Hungary to Become an Illiberal Model
item.description: After years of complacency and wishful thinking, Brussels is finally trying to rein in the country’s pugnacious leader, Prime Minister Viktor Orban.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary in June. The position he has put the bloc in says much about why it has stumbled in the face of populist challenges.

item.title: Trump Endorses Viktor Orban, Hungary’s Far-Right Prime Minister
item.description: Democracy in Hungary has been backsliding under Mr. Orban, whose efforts to consolidate power have caused consternation in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Viktor Orban, left, was an early supporter of former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Canada Pledges 40 Billion Dollars in Indigenous Child Welfare Battle
item.description: The government said it would pay a landmark 40 billion Canadian dollars to repair the system, potentially ending a lawsuit brought 15 years ago.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for the children found in unmarked graves last year near the Kamloops Indian Residential School in British Columbia.

item.title: CDC Recommends a Pfizer Booster Shot After 5 Months, Not 6
item.description: Following the F.D.A.’s lead, the agency also recommended third shots after four weeks for some immunocompromised children 5 to 11.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: M. Scott Brauer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The move comes as the highly contagious Omicron variant has infected a record daily average of Americans.

item.title: Sweden’s king and queen test positive for the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Aina J. Khan
item.media:description: Queen Silvia and King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a Nobel Prize ceremony in Stockholm in December.

item.title: Djokovic Granted Covid-19 Vaccine Exemption to Play in Australian Open
item.description: The top-ranked player in men’s tennis revealed his plans in a post on his Instagram account.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Das
item.media:description: Novak Djokovic in Turin, Italy, in November.

item.title: Hong Kong expands its vaccine requirements as it fights to control Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A vaccination center in Hong Kong last month. The city has fully vaccinated only about 69 percent of its population, according to the government.

item.title: With Property Sales Plunging, China Evergrande Faces More Protests
item.description: The developer has tried for months to signal that its $300 billion debt problem was under control. But the challenges keep mounting.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard outside the Evergrande International Center in Guangzhou, China, on Tuesday, where protesters gathered to seek repayment from the Evergrande Group.

item.title: No Way to Grow Up
item.description: For the past two years, Americans have accepted more harm to children in exchange for less harm to adults.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Idle school buses in Detroit yesterday.

item.title: Philippines Expands Lockdown for Unvaccinated Around Manila
item.description: The new rules bar unvaccinated residents from leaving their homes except for a list of essential reasons.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez
item.media:description: Cleaning a classroom in an elementary school following a suspension of face to face classes in Marikina City, Metro Manila, Philippines, on Monday.

item.title: A Widening Web of Undersea Cables Connects Britain to Green Energy
item.description: Linking one nation’s power grid with another’s is considered essential as more electricity is generated from solar and wind.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: A direct current conversion facility in Blyth, England, provides a landing point for a new cable stretching from Norway.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: U.S. struggles to avoid Omicron shutdowns.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers at U.S. airports were forced to wait hours in long lines.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Global Covid cases reach record highs
item.description: But recent Omicron data offer hope.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up for a rapid Covid test in Paris last week.

item.title: April Ashley, London Socialite and Transgender Pioneer, Dies at 86
item.description: She modeled for Vogue, partied with John Lennon and Mick Jagger, and married into minor nobility, all while fighting for legal recognition of her gender.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Victim of Berkeley Balcony Collapse Dies in Ireland
item.description: Aoife Beary, who was left with life-changing injuries after the 2015 accident, died on New Year’s Day, her family said.
item.dc:creator: Ed O’Loughlin
item.media:description: Inspectors examining the balcony after the collapse in 2015 in Berkeley, Calif.

item.title: South Africa Parliament: Suspect Charged in Fire to Appear in Court
item.description: A 49-year-old man is facing charges of arson and theft in the blaze, which started Sunday and heavily damaged legislative buildings in Cape Town.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the Houses of Parliament in Cape Town on Monday.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Tunisia’s President to Salvage the Economy
item.description: When President Kais Saied seized power in July, he vowed to rescue the failing economy. Tunisians are still waiting for him to fulfill that pledge.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fish market in Tunis. The price of basic food items is climbing in Tunisia.

item.title: As the pandemic wears on Americans, mild disappointments lead to bad behavior.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Checking in at Kennedy Airport in New York the day after Christmas. In 2021, there were 5,779 reports of unruly passengers on planes, most of them related to mask mandates, the Federal Aviation Administration says.

item.title: How Beijing Has Muted Hong Kong’s Independent Media
item.description: Citizen News, a small but aggressive online publication, is the latest outlet to fold amid relentless pressure from the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Stand News Editor Patrick Lam being escorted into a police van in Hong Kong last month.

item.title: Online ‘Auction’ Is Latest Attack on Muslim Women in India
item.description: The fake site, the second in months, is a sign of the organized nature of virtual bullying, with threats of sexualized violence aimed at silencing the outspoken.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: A Muslim woman walking past an image of Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Kochi, Kerala State, last year.

item.title: Brazil's President, Jair Bolsonaro, Is Hospitalized
item.description: Mr. Bolsonaro, who was stabbed while on the campaign trail in 2018, experienced stomach discomfort during his vacation and was flown back to São Paulo.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño and Flávia Milhorance
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil in November. The injuries he sustained in 2018 required at least four surgeries.

item.title: Reason for Hope
item.description: We look back on the pandemic — and ahead to its next phases — with a handful of charts.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ashley Wu
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Entering Times Square on New Year's Eve.

item.title: The pandemic brought seismic changes, and inspired remarkable resilience.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:credit: Rich-Joseph Facun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Finazzo, 35, lost his job as a brewer during the shutdown and was inspired by the pandemic to become a microbiologist.

item.title: The child tax credit’s extra help has ended just as a Covid threat rises anew.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Lara and her partner, Jeremy Finley, with their children at a park in Huntington, W. Va. The child benefit helped the couple make ends meet at a time of reduced income and rising prices.

item.title: Celebrating the ‘Great Night of Shiva’ in Kathmandu
item.description: Every year, thousands of celebrants gather at a temple complex in Nepal’s capital in honor of Shiva, one of Hinduism’s most revered gods.
item.dc:creator: Shelby Tauber
item.media:description: The temple complex of Pashupatinath, on the banks of the Bagmati River.

item.title: Richard Leakey, Kenyan Fossil Hunter and Conservationist, Dies at 77
item.description: His discoveries of ancient human skulls and skeletons, including the famed “Turkana Boy,” helped cement Africa’s standing as the cradle of humanity.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Christine Chung
item.media:description: Richard Leakey in 1977 with two crucial skull discoveries — Australopithecus, left, and “1470,” Homo habilis.

item.title: China Evergrande Suspends Trading Shares in Hong Kong
item.description: The world’s most indebted property developer provided no details on the suspension, but it suggested an announcement “containing inside information” would come soon.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: An unfinished residential development by China Evergrande Group in Suzhou, Jiangsu Province, in October.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A crisis in Bosnia.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Whet Moser

item.title: U.S. Defense Secretary Tests Positive for Coronavirus
item.description: Lloyd J. Austin III stressed that his fully vaccinated status — including a booster received in early October — was to thank for his mild symptoms.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin said his symptoms were mild and that he would work from home for the next five days.

item.title: Sudan’s Prime Minister, Abdalla Hamdok, Resigns
item.description: Mr. Hamdok was restored to power a month ago after being deposed in a coup, but he was never able to gain control of the fractious country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: People chant slogans during a protest to denounce the October 2021 military coup, in Khartoum on Sunday.

item.title: Israel will offer a 4th Covid shot to people 60 and over.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Health care workers giving out booster shots in Jerusalem in August.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: South Africa’s Parliament Burns
item.description: Plus a breach in the DMZ and posturing about women’s rights in China.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Smoke billowed from the National Assembly building in Cape Town where a fire broke out in the early hours of the morning on Sunday.

item.title: Wellness vacations go beyond massages and diet tips during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León

item.title: Governor: Maryland Prepares for 'Terrible Point' in Covid Crisis
item.description: Gov. Larry Hogan said the state was trying to staff hospitals through a variety of measures.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland in Annapolis in August.

item.title: Venice to Replace Glass on Santiago Calatrava's Slippery Bridge
item.description: The city will replace the glass on Santiago Calatrava’s footbridge across the Grand Canal with stone after too many pedestrians fell.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ponte della Costituzione was meant to symbolize Venice’s embrace of modernity, but it has become better known for tumbles and slips.

item.title: Americans are bracing for the return to school and work.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch, Stephanie Saul, Edgar Sandoval and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Andrea Ellen Reed for The New York Times
item.media:description: School officials are reconsidering whether to reopen classrooms amid a nationwide surge in Covid cases.

item.title: In the Tinderbox of Bosnia, a Serb Nationalist Lights a Match
item.description: Bosnia’s fragile multiethnic government is facing its greatest crisis since the Balkan wars. The Serb nationalist leader, Milorad Dodik, is threatening to tear the country apart.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A monument in Prijedor, Bosnia, commemorating Bosnian Serb soldiers killed in the 1990s. Many Serbs like Milorad Dodik deny war crimes committed by ethnic kin and see themselves as victims.

item.title: China Moves to Overhaul Protections for Women’s Rights, Sort Of
item.description: The proposed revisions to a women’s rights law would be the first major changes in nearly 20 years. But many women are skeptical that real progress will follow.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Supporters of Zhou Xiaoxuan in Beijing. Ms. Zhou, a prominent voice in China’s #MeToo movement, doubts the draft laws will change much. “This is probably still a very long, hard road,” she said.

item.title: A Spanish Mystery: Is a ‘Masked Restorer’ to Blame for a Church’s Botched Repair?
item.description: Yet another imprudent fix in a land plagued by vigilante handymen led to angry calls to find the culprit — and to a soul-searching question: Does Spain just have too much history in need of upkeep?
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Ben Roberts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Church of Santa María del Castillo in the Spanish village of Castronuño was built around 1250.

item.title: South Korea Says Unknown Person Crossed DMZ Into North
item.description: The breach at the Demilitarized Zone went unnoticed for hours, the South Korean military said. There was no immediate response from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Soldiers in 2019 at the Demilitarized Zone in Gangwon Province in South Korea.

item.title: South Africa Parliament Is 'Gutted' by Large Fire
item.description: Officials warned that the damage to the buildings would be extensive. A man was arrested on Sunday morning inside the parliamentary complex, Parliament’s spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Smoke rising above the National Assembly on Sunday in Cape Town.

item.title: New York reports 85,000 cases in a day, another record, as surge shows no sign of slowing.
item.dc:creator: Louis Lucero II
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Crowds gathered in Times Square in Manhattan on New Year’s Eve. The state reported a record number of new cases on Saturday.

item.title: A crew outbreak halts a German New Year’s cruise in Lisbon.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The cruise ship AIDAnova in the port of Lisbon on Saturday. The ship had been making a short stop but was held at the port after more than 50 crew members tested positive.

item.title: A Vatican Library Shortens the Distance Between Its Works and Its Scholars
item.description: Rare books in Rome are going online thanks to a German copier, a Long Island scanning firm and a New York software company.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Rev. David Nazar, the rector of the Pontifical Oriental Institute. The collaboration to digitize its books reminded him of a “Mickey Rooney film.”

item.title: New Year’s Day charity swims are being canceled around the world.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:description: Last year’s Loony Dook New Year’s Eve cold water swim in Edinburgh. That swim, like many other such New Year’s events, will not take place on Saturday because of surging coronavirus cases.
